abstract.text: The attributes of a pixel format.

inlineContent.text: If you need to define a custom pixel format, you must specify these keys in a Core Foundation dictionary. For information about registering your pixel format, see
In most cases you do not need to specify your own pixel format.

abstract.text: Process digital video, including manipulation of individual frames, using a pipeline-based API and support for both Metal and OpenGL.
Defines a pointer to a custom extended pixel-fill function, which is called whenever the system needs to pad a buffer holding your custom pixel format.
A structure for holding information that describes a custom extended pixel fill algorithm.
An API that provides functions and types for defining custom pixel formats.
The bit pattern for a block of black pixels (type
. If this key is absent, black is assumed to be all zeros. If present, this should be
bits long; if
is less than a byte, repeat the bit pattern for the full byte.
The height, in pixels, of the smallest byte-addressable group of pixels (type
). Assumed to be 1 if this key is not present.
The horizontal alignment requirements of this format (type
). For example,the alignment for v210 would be 8 here for the horizontal case to match the standard v210 row alignment value of 48. Assumed to be 1 if this key is not present.
The vertical alignment requirements of this format (type
). Assumed to be 1 if this key is not present.

A Boolean value where
indicates that the format contains alpha and some images may be considered transparent;
indicates that there is no alpha and images are always opaque.

). Assumed to be 1 if this key is not present.
The name of the pixel format (type
). This should be the same as the codec name you would use in QuickTime.

Core Video does not provide support for all of these formats; this list defines only their names.
